title: Students experience agronomy through crop scouting competition

subtasks: Arrive at UK's Research and Education Center on a cloudy morning
Rotate through ten stations within the competition
Engage in hands-on activities related to various agricultural topics
Learn about weed identification (e.g., morning glory)
Practice scouting techniques for crops like corn and soybeans
Observe and assess plant growth stages
Interact with University of Kentucky faculty, graduate students, and interns
Gain educational experience relevant to future agricultural studies or careers
Participate as a high school crop scouting team member
Collaborate with teammates (four to six members per team)
Complete tasks at each of the ten competition stations
Receive guidance from University of Kentucky specialists at the stations
Acquire knowledge in areas such as soil properties, insect management, and agronomy
Organize the student competition involving eight teams
Coordinate rotation schedules for teams through the ten stations
Develop and oversee the ten stations' activities
Prepare materials or setups for each station (e.g., soil samples, plant specimens, pest displays)
Educate student participants on agricultural topics through direct interaction

tasks.task: Media coverage of the crop scouting competition
subtasks: Report on the event as a journalist (Jeff Franklin)
Describe the venue and facilities at UK's Research and Education Center
Interview organizers and educators about the competition's purpose and benefits
Highlight student feedback on the educational value of the event
Announce plans for future iterations of the competition
